Science and Engineering

Lights in the Night

The stars that adorn our night sky are a wonder to behold. Some of them are similar to our Sun. Some are smaller and redder. Others are much bigger and brighter. All of them are farther from Earth than you can imagine.

The only information we get by looking at stars with the naked eye is how bright they appear. Because they are scattered over such an immense range of distances, a star's apparent brightness has little bearing on how bright it actually is.

Stars emit light equally in all directions at a rate that's constant from year to year. (Over billions of years, the output of a star can change, but it rarely changes over shorter times.) If you were on a planet closer to the Sun, the Sun would appear brighter, but its output hasn't actually changed. It's brighter to you because more of its energy hits your eye each second.

You experience this same effect driving at night. Car headlights are visible several kilometers away, but they aren't blinding until the car is about to pass you. The intensity of the lights has increased, but the actual brightness of the lights hasn't.

To be more precise about this idea, let's say a star is radiating energy at a rate of PPP (which stands for power). No matter how near or far the star is from you, PPP is always the same.

If you built a shell that completely surrounded this star, you could harness all its power. (This speculative structure, called a Dyson sphere, could supply a more advanced civilization with nearly limitless energy.) The energy hitting the shell would be divided evenly across each point on the shell, provided it is centered on the star.

Even if the shell had a different radius r,r,r, the power PPP you harvest would be the same — you're still getting all the energy. However, for larger r,r,r, the amount of light falling on each bit of the shell's area is smaller. In other words, the intensity of the light is lower on a larger shell.

By this reasoning, the intensity of light at a distance of rrr away from the source emitting power PPP is equal to P4πr2,\frac{P}{4\pi r^2},4πr2P​, where 4πr24\pi r^24πr2 is the surface area of a shell at a distance of r.r.r.

This pattern of light spreading out with distance doesn’t just apply to light from stars — any radiation from a point source will spread out in the same way. Using the tool below, you can see how the intensity changes with the power of a light source PPP and your distance rrr from it.

P{\color{#333333}P}P
P{\color{#333333}P}P

Notice that, each time you double your distance from the lighthouse, the intensity of light received from it decreases by a factor of four. The farther you are from the source, the greater the distance you will need to travel to experience this change in intensity.

Today's Challenge

You are sailing in the dark toward two lights, which look equally bright.

A few minutes later you look at them again and the light on the left appears brighter than the one on the right.

Assuming that the powers of the light sources haven’t changed and that the lights aren't moving relative to each other, which one is giving off more light?

The left light is more powerful. The right light is more powerful. Either one could more powerful.

Incorrect

Let's use maths :)

Let the initial distance between you and the left and right lights be r1r_1r1​ and r2r_2r2​ respectively.

It is given that initially, both lights have equal intensity from your point of view.

By the formula, we can get this equation:

I1=I2P14πr12=P24πr22P1=(r1r2)2P2\begin{aligned} I_1&=I_2\\ \frac{P_1}{4\pi r_1^2}&=\frac{P_2}{4\pi r_2^2}\\ P_1&=\left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^2P_2 \end{aligned}I1​4πr12​P1​​P1​​=I2​=4πr22​P2​​=(r2​r1​​)2P2​​

Assume then you moved a distance xxx towards both lights, such that 0<x<min⁡(r1,r2)0<x<\min(r_1,r_2)0<x<min(r1​,r2​).

Since it is also given that after you moved, the light on the left has a greater intensity now, we can again use the formula to get an inequality:

I1′>I2′P14π(r1−x)2>P24π(r2−x)2P1>(r1−xr2−x)2P2\begin{aligned} I_1^\prime&>I_2^\prime\\ \frac{P_1}{4\pi\left(r_1-x\right)^2}&>\frac{P_2}{4\pi\left(r_2-x\right)^2}\\ P_1&>\left(\frac{r_1-x}{r_2-x}\right)^2P_2 \end{aligned}I1′​4π(r1​−x)2P1​​P1​​>I2′​>4π(r2​−x)2P2​​>(r2​−xr1​−x​)2P2​​

Since we already know that P1=(r1r2)2P2P_1=\left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^2P_2P1​=(r2​r1​​)2P2​, we can substitute that into our inequality, and get:

(r1r2)2P2>(r1−xr2−x)2P2(r1r2)2>(r1−xr2−x)2r1r2>r1−xr2−xr1r2−xr1>r1r2−xr2−xr1>−xr2r2>r1\begin{aligned} \left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^2P_2&>\left(\frac{r_1-x}{r_2-x}\right)^2P_2\\ \left(\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)^2&>\left(\frac{r_1-x}{r_2-x}\right)^2\\ \frac{r_1}{r_2}&>\frac{r_1-x}{r_2-x}\\ r_1r_2-xr_1&>r_1r_2-xr_2\\ -xr_1&>-xr_2\\ r_2&>r_1 \end{aligned}(r2​r1​​)2P2​(r2​r1​​)2r2​r1​​r1​r2​−xr1​−xr1​r2​​>(r2​−xr1​−x​)2P2​>(r2​−xr1​−x​)2>r2​−xr1​−x​>r1​r2​−xr2​>−xr2​>r1​​

Now we can use this result to deduce whether P1P_1P1​ or P2P_2P2​ is larger. To do that, first express PPP in terms of III:

I=P4πr2  ⟹  P=4πr2II=\frac{P}{4\pi r^2}\implies P=4\pi r^2II=4πr2P​⟹P=4πr2I

Then, we can apply the inequality from before:

r2>r1r22>r124πr22>4πr12\begin{aligned} r_2&>r_1\\ r_2^2&>r_1^2\\ 4\pi r_2^2&>4\pi r_1^2 \end{aligned}r2​r22​4πr22​​>r1​>r12​>4πr12​​

From the very top, we already know that I1=I2I_1=I_2I1​=I2​, so we can multiply the left by I1I_1I1​ and right by I2I_2I2​ while still preserving the inequality.

4πI2r22>4πI1r12P2>P1\begin{aligned} 4\pi I_2r_2^2&>4\pi I_1r_1^2\\ P_2&>P_1 \end{aligned}4πI2​r22​P2​​>4πI1​r12​>P1​​

Therefore, the right light is more powerful.

PS In the working above, I am allowed to divide, square, take square roots and cross-multiply on both sides of the inequalities because everything is positive. In general, I cannot do that so mindlessly lol. Also, for light sources that are far away, they are roughly in the same direction.

If therefore III is equal for both light sources, the one closer by (smaller ddd) becomes brighter at a faster rate.

Ed Robertson
Jun 28, 2020

This can be solved very quickly using logic. Consider the following:

1) both lights initially appear to have the same intensity (brightness)

2) The intensity of one light changes more rapidly than the other, and I = P / (4pir^2)

3) Distance squared is a powerful divisor, so if you subtract a small amount, d, from both r1 and r2, and r2 is larger, then (r1-d)^2 will charge more than (r2-d)^2, in proportion

If you doubt this, start with r1 =10 and r2=25. Move 5 units closer. r1’=5 and r2’=20. The ratios of the squares are 100:25 and 625:400. The intensity for the closer light source changes by a factor of 4.

This is conceptually, although not mathematically similar to the recent parallax challenge.

For a very clear mathematical explanation, see Gandoff Tan’s solution.

The brightness or intensity of light of a light III is directly proportional to the power PPP of the light source and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the light and the observer rrr. In formula it is: I=kPr2I = \frac {kP}{r^2}I=r2kP​ where kkk is a constant.

In the beginning, the brightness of the light on the left I1I_1I1​ and the brightness of the light on the right I2I_2I2​ appears to be the same. Then we have:

I1=I2kP1r12=kP2r22  ⟹  P2P1=r22r12\begin{aligned} I_1 & = I_2 \\ \frac {kP_1}{r_1^2} & = \frac {kP_2}{r_2^2} \\ \implies \frac {P_2}{P_1} & = \frac {r_2^2}{r_1^2} \end{aligned} I1​r12​kP1​​⟹P1​P2​​​=I2​=r22​kP2​​=r12​r22​​​

After traveling a distance ddd toward the lights later, the brightness of the light on the left I1′I'_1I1′​ is given by:

I1′I1=r12(r1−d)2  ⟹  I1′=r12(r1−d)2I1\frac {I'_1}{I_1} = \frac {r_1^2}{(r_1-d)^2} \implies I'_1 = \frac {r_1^2}{(r_1-d)^2} I_1I1​I1′​​=(r1​−d)2r12​​⟹I1′​=(r1​−d)2r12​​I1​

Similarly that for the light on the right is

I2′I2=r22(r2−d)2  ⟹  I2′=r22(r2−d)2I2\frac {I'_2}{I_2} = \frac {r_2^2}{(r_2-d)^2} \implies I'_2 = \frac {r_2^2}{(r_2-d)^2} I_2I2​I2′​​=(r2​−d)2r22​​⟹I2′​=(r2​−d)2r22​​I2​

Since I1′>I2′I'_1 > I'_2I1′​>I2′​, we have:

r12(r1−d)2I1>r22(r2−d)2I2Note that I1=I2(r1r1−d)2>(r2r2−d)2(1+dr1−d)2>(1+dr2−d)2  ⟹  r1<r2\begin{aligned} \frac {r_1^2}{(r_1-d)^2} I_1 & > \frac {r_2^2}{(r_2-d)^2} I_2 & \small \blue{\text{Note that }I_1= I_2} \\ \left(\frac {r_1}{r_1-d}\right)^2 & > \left(\frac {r_2}{r_2-d}\right)^2 \\ \left(1+\frac d{r_1-d}\right)^2 & > \left(1+\frac d{r_2-d}\right)^2 \\ \implies r_1 & < r_2 \end{aligned} (r1​−d)2r12​​I1​(r1​−dr1​​)2(1+r1​−dd​)2⟹r1​​>(r2​−d)2r22​​I2​>(r2​−dr2​​)2>(1+r2​−dd​)2<r2​​Note that I1​=I2​

SInce P2P1=r22r12\dfrac {P_2}{P_1} = \dfrac {r_2^2}{r_1^2}P1​P2​​=r12​r22​​ and r2>r1r_2 > r_1r2​>r1​,   ⟹  P2>P1\implies P_2 > P_1⟹P2​>P1​. The right light is more powerful.

Andrew Last
Jun 28, 2020

As stated in the Waves and Light course, "luminosity [power] is a fixed property," whereas "intensity [brightness] varies with the distance of the observer."

Since the intensity of L increases more than R, we can conclude that the observer is closer to L than to R.

In order for R to appear as bright as L from further away, it must give off more light.

Rl0 = Initial distance to the left light, Rr0 = Initial distance to the right light, Rl1 = Final distance to the left light, Rr1 = Final distance to the right light.

In the beginning, It seemed they were at the same distance. However, when you approached, the left light was brighter. That is because initially, the ratio Rl0 to Rr0, Rl0/Rr0, was almost one but Rr0 was slightly bigger.

When they approach, the ratio Rl1 to Rr1, Rl1/Rr1, was almost zero. That means that the right one was more powerful because at the beginning, at a longer distance, it had the same intensity as the nearest left, but his intensity decreased because the distances' ratio decreased as well.

Jun 28, 2020

At first, you receive a similar amount of light, but that doesn't necessarily mean that they have the same power, since one can be farther than the other and be more powerful.

The light emitted from a point gets dispersed from the origin, because light is travelling in a straight line, so that lines are farther from each other the farther they are from the focus. Here we've got a picture:

We see that that is what's happening a few minutes later: the left seems brighter, so it's light is less dispersed than the other. We can deduce then that the other is more powerful because we see now that, at first, they seemed equal, but we know that the left is less dispersed, so it's less powerful than the right one, that is emitting more light but it's more dispersed.

A key fact here is that, the farther you go, the less you see the intensity of the light decrease, so, you are farther from the right light than from the left one, because, travelling, you see more difference in the left one.

Amir Vafaie
Jun 28, 2020

That the lights have the same brightness means one of two cases:

a) both have the same power and are at the same distance from us,

b) they have different powers and the one closer to us is less powerful.

The function 1r2\frac {1}{r^2}r21​ looks in the first quadrant like the picture below. It can be seen that for a fixed change x in distance from the source, the closer one is to the source, the greater the change in Intensity is. That after a few minutes the light on the left looks brighter means that the lights are not at the same distance and that we are closer to the light on the left. This means that the light on the right is more powerful.

Forgive me, for this is definitely missing things. I solved this through potentially faulty conceptual logic rather than math. Please correct me, add info, reword, etc.

Since the position and power source of each light remains constant throughout the scenario, we can assume that the left light became brighter due to the sailboat decreasing distance between us and the light sources.

This indicates that the light source on the left is closer to us than the light source on the right because:

  • The light on the left is becoming increasingly brighter more quickly than the light on the right.
  • When calculating apparent brightness, (b=L4πd2b = \frac{L}{4πd^2}b=4πd2L​, where ddd is distance and LLL is luminosity), distance is the most weighted factor, meaning that a change in distance would more significantly affect apparent brightness than would an equivalent change in luminosity. Therefore, the brightness is much more likely due to a smaller distance rather than a greater luminosity. (This is where I'm having trouble. How can I logically rule out a scenario where the light on the right is closer with very low luminosity, while the left is further with a significantly increased luminosity?)

Upon deducting that the light on the left is closer, we can also deduct that it is weaker, because there was a point in time when both lights had the same apparent brightness, yet the light on the right was further from us than the light on the left. This means the light on the right has a higher luminosity.

this one seems fairly simple; if the left light become more bright when you went closer, it means this light is weaker; in other words, the right light didn't change as much in brightness, meaning its farther; but this might be missing some reasoning;

so say the intensity of a light source is proportional to the square of the distance between the observer and it, then once you moved closer, the intensity of the light on the left rose, so it must mean that the distance to this light is small enough where approaching it after just a few minutes was significant enough to allow the sailor to perceive different light intensity. The distance to the right light is large enough where a few minutes closer distance is not significant enough to change the perception of intensity.

Of course there could also be other reasons (suppose some guardsman decided to change the left light to a more intense light or something), but given this problem's context its safe to use the above reasoning to arrive at an answer the question assumes to seek.

Stewart Copeland
Jun 28, 2020

Law: the intensity of a light source decreases with the inverse of the distance squared from the observer. If the light on the left is as bright as the one on the right, we can make three assumptions:

  • 1) the 2 lights emit the same energy and are at the same distance from the observer

  • 2) the light on the left emits more energy than that on the right but is farther from the observer

  • 3) the light on the right emits more energy than that on the left but is further from the observer.

--> As the light on the left shines more than that on the right when the observer gets closer to the sources, it is hypothesis n° 3 which turns out to be correct
